title: Republicans weigh battle over filibuster rules
authors: Jake Sherman, Rachael Bade, Seung Min Kim
content:
Frustrated with Democrats blocking their agenda , a cadre of upstart Republicans is pushing to revamp the Senate ’ s rule book to make it harder for the opposition to keep key legislation from coming to the floor .
But the move pits the maverick conservatives against the party ’ s “ old bulls ” — such as Arizona Republican Sen. John McCain — who argue the changes would erode key rights of the minority and undermine how the Senate was designed to work . Many of the upstarts have never been in the minority , but veteran Republicans are wary of taking bold action now that could haunt them if they ever lose control of the chamber .
The rabble-rousers are targeting the 60-vote threshold to start debate on government spending measures — a threshold Senate Democrats used to their advantage this year by filibustering all funding bills and ultimately forcing budget negotiations that led to a sweeping fiscal deal last week .
“ I think it ’ s appropriate to be able to debate a bill without having to have a 60-vote margin , ” said Sen. Mike Rounds ( R-S.D. ) . “ I think when they originally put the rules in place , it was a mistake not to have made that change in the first place . ”
The growing push , reflected in interviews with more than a dozen GOP senators , is the latest example of the majority party — irritated by a filibuster-wielding opposition — looking at ways to limit minority rights since Senate Democrats activated the so-called nuclear option two years ago to speed the approval of most White House nominations .
Now , the calls for procedural war are growing louder . Though earlier fights generally centered on nominations , a core group of senators had always been able to strike deals that staved off any major rewrites of the Senate ’ s rules — such as the so-called Gang of 14 senators that reached an agreement on nominees under the Bush administration . Senators had also reached agreements to back down from going nuclear under President Barack Obama .
But then Senate Democrats deployed the nuclear option in November 2013 to lower the voting threshold for nearly all nominations . Since then , Republicans have been more willing to openly entertain their own proposals on altering the Senate ’ s operations .
Sen. Steve Daines ( R-Mont . ) , a former House member who was elected to the Senate last year , agrees that it ’ s time for a change .
“ What it does is it allows us to get these bills on the floor for debate , ” Daines said of dumping the 60-vote threshold to bring spending bills to the floor . “ The Senate has been referred to as the greatest deliberative body . This would help that deliberative body deliberate more by getting the bills on the floor for debate . ”
“ I like the idea of 51 to move . I used to would not , ” said Sen. Richard Shelby ( R-Ala. ) , a senior member of the Appropriations Committee . He said the Democrats ’ nuclear option two years ago “ changed the game , ” and added : “ You know , it ’ s not the law . It ’ s not the statute . It ’ s not the Constitution . ”
Republicans are particularly steamed at Democrats for voting to advance appropriations bills through the committee but filibustering them on the floor . The three funding bills that Democrats blocked in the full Senate this year — defense , military construction and veterans affairs , and energy and water — all passed the Appropriations Committee with healthy bipartisan majorities .
The growing appetite to change the rules also shows how frustration from House GOP lawmakers is having some influence on their Senate-side colleagues .
A chief complaint from House members is that the Senate — often paralyzed by a Democratic filibuster — is unable to move key bills , even though Republicans control both ends of the Capitol . House lawmakers began urging the Senate to nuke the filibuster earlier this year , when the 60-vote threshold prevented the upper chamber from advancing a funding bill for the Department of Homeland Security that would override Obama ’ s executive actions on immigration .
“ I ’ m actually pretty bullish on changing all the rules as I know them , quite frankly , ” said Sen. Tim Scott ( R-S.C. ) , who is also a former House lawmaker . “ Nominations , everything … I ’ m open to anything that makes this body actually functioning . ”
The rising sentiment from GOP senators may have little practical effect , since Senate Republicans broadly believe they would need Democratic buy-in to change the chamber ’ s rules . Senate Democrats went nuclear to change the rules two years ago , meaning they did so with a simple majority of 51 votes — effectively cutting out Republicans , who have since sworn that any rules changes that come under a GOP majority would require 67 votes in the Senate .
A group assigned by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R-Ky. ) is poring through arcane procedural precedent to see what rules changes are possible . Led by GOP Sens . Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Roy Blunt of Missouri , the five senators on that task force want to offer some ideas for rules reforms while ensuring that minority rights are still protected . McConnell himself has said little publicly about his preference on rules changes , except that any alterations should go through regular order , not by going nuclear .
A Republican aide said the group has met twice , with more discussions to come . And Alexander said he hopes to present potential options for rules changes to the broader GOP Conference “ in the next few weeks. ” The other GOP senators who are part of the group are Sens . James Lankford of Oklahoma , Thom Tillis of North Carolina and Cory Gardner of Colorado .
Tillis said lowering the threshold for cloture on a motion to proceed on appropriations from 60 to 51 is under consideration as part of those discussions . He , along with several other Senate Republicans , emphasized that the Senate should still require 60 votes to invoke cloture on the back end and advance legislation to final passage .
“ It ’ s not the extreme position , ” Tillis said of abandoning the initial 60-vote threshold . “ This is really , how do you make the process more efficient and what kinds of things can you do to maintain the basic rules of the game but allow us to get a few more plays in ? ”
Added Sen. Ron Johnson ( R-Wis. ) : “ I think that ’ s not a bad idea . ”
“ Watching how we are not utilizing the process , that could work , ” Johnson said . “ That ’ s an idea certainly worth considering , but only on the motion to proceed . ”
Tensions over the legislative filibuster have flared , not just on Capitol Hill this year , but on the 2016 campaign trail as well . A few Republican presidential contenders have called on the Senate to gut the filibuster — primarily to repeal Obamacare and disapprove Obama ’ s nuclear deal with Iran — although sitting senators running for their respective party nominations generally have declined to go that far .
The issue was even slipped into the recent budget negotiations , with McConnell asking Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid whether the Nevada Democrat would agree on a way to ease filibusters on appropriations bills . Reid swiftly objected to the proposal .
“ As I have told Republicans to their faces , if you want to have an appropriations process , then understand the Senate ’ s different than the House , ” Reid said in a recent interview with ███ . “ I ’ m sure [ former Speaker John ] Boehner , I ’ m sure [ Speaker Paul ] Ryan , [ House Appropriations Committee Chairman Hal ] Rogers obviously , they would love to write rules for the Senate . But we do not want the Senate to be like the House . ”
Despite the rising desire among many Senate Republicans to alter the rules , any changes limiting minority rights are likely to run into resistance from veteran GOP senators who ’ ve served in both the majority and minority — and have seen both the upsides and downsides of the power of the filibuster .
“ I tend to be an institutionalist who really is hesitant to change the rules because I think it usually boomerangs on you , ” said Sen. Susan Collins ( R-Maine ) . “ And a lot of times , it ’ s done for short-term political advantage without taking into account the history of the Senate . ”
McCain , who like Collins was part of the Gang of 14 a decade ago , also warned against changes to the filibuster rules , no matter how minor . For him , any tweak would lead to a “ slippery slope . ”
“ Every one of these Republican senators now that are saying we should consider 51 votes on appropriations bills were hard against 51 votes for judicial appointees two years ago , ” McCain said . “ So where ’ s the consistency ? ”
